byline.original: By JERÉ LONGMAN and JOE WARD

abstract: Many athletes competing in track and field events at 2016  Rio Olympics plan to camouflage logos of non-sponsor brands on their footwear using creative combination of paint, tape and other methods of disguise; hiding logos of competing brands allows athletes to wear their choice of footwear, item particularly important to performance, without offending sponsors in powerful $75 billion global athletic footwear industry.
lead_paragraph: Although it is unclear how many athletes will be disguising their footwear at the Rio Games, the practice is common at track meets, for various reasons.
snippet: Although it is unclear how many athletes will be disguising their footwear at the Rio Games, the practice is common at track meets, for various reasons....

headline.main: Olympic Cover-Up: Why You Won’t See Some Shoe Logos
headline.print_headline: Competing for Olympic Fame, Wearing Brand X on Their Feet
